Schizophrenia (in the context of associated autoimmune diseases)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, leading to pain and swelling.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders such as hyperthyroidism can cause joint pain, hyperactivity, and dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, leading to cysts on the ovaries, and can also affect blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose), potentially leading to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean fever
diagnoses.description: An inherited condition that often causes fever and inflammation in the abdomen, chest, or joints.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the accumulation of mast cells in the body's tissues, which can lead to skin and systemic symptoms, including dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones, leading to joint pain and potential hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, sometimes associated with joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other tissues and organs, potentially causing joint pain and cysts.

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses. In your case, this diagnosis corresponds directly with one of the given symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.description: A condition causing creamy white lesions, usually on your tongue or inner cheeks. It could correlate with the symptom of leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins, such as B12 or zinc, may lead to symptoms like dysgeusia and possibly contribute indirectly to conditions like leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: This condition might present with thrombocytosis and could also relate to dysgeusia due to the impact on the body's nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that can cause dysgeusia due to the accumulation of toxins and can also contribute to thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that produces an abnormal increase in white blood cells (thrombocytosis) and can present with symptoms such as leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Oral Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that develops in any of the parts that make up the mouth. Leukoplakia can be a symptom, and advanced cases may lead to altered taste (dysgeusia).

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder in which your bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. It can also cause thrombocytosis and has been associated with dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, which could potentially cause dysgeusia and leukoplakia due to the lack of moisture.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, this infectious disease can cause symptoms such as thrombocytosis and might have implications for oral health, potentially leading to conditions like leukoplakia.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare type of bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, causing extensive scarring in bone marrow. This can lead to anemia, weakness, fatigue, and often bone pain, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause bone pain, fatigue, weakness, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Osteoporosis
diagnoses.description: A condition that weakens bones, making them fragile and more likely to break. It can cause osteopenia and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell, causing cancerous plasma cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells. It often leads to bone pain and osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. In some cases, it can cause dyspnea and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While primarily affecting joints, it can also cause bone pain and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: An excessive production of parathyroid hormone that can lead to osteopenia, kidney stones, and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: A condition often stemming from chronic hypoxia or, less commonly, a tumor producing erythropoietin. It may cause increased red blood cells, dyspnea, but can be associated with sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Insufficient vitamin D in the body can lead to bone pain and osteopenia due to impaired bone mineralization.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that, over time, can cause some of the vertebrae in the spine to fuse. This condition can cause chronic pain and stiffness in the back and sometimes peripheral joints.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus Type 2
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Increased appetite (polyphagia) and hypoglycemia can be manifestations, especially in poorly controlled cases or during treatment adjustments. Hypertension is often comorbid.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the pancreas that produces too much insulin, leading to hypoglycemia. Patients may experience increased appetite as a response to low blood sugar levels. Hypertension can be related to the episodic hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can cause symptoms like increased appetite and word-finding difficulties. Hypothyroidism can also raise cholesterol levels, which may contribute to hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol in the blood. Symptoms often include hypertension, increased appetite, and glucose intolerance, which can lead to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects hormone levels in women, leading to prolonged or infrequent menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. It is commonly associated with obesity, which can cause hypertension, increased appetite, and insulin resistance, leading to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Some medications for other conditions can cause increased appetite, hypoglycemia, and hypertension as side effects. Careful review of the patient's mediations is necessary.

diagnoses.name: Mental Health Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as depression or generalized anxiety disorder can indirectly lead to increased appetite and weight gain. Cognitive symptoms such as word-finding difficulty may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions include increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol levels.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It results in the release of too much epinephrine and norepinephrine, hormones that regulate heart rate and blood pressure, leading to hypertension. Hypoglycemia can occur post-adrenaline surges.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of fluid and wastes in the body, affecting many systems. It can be associated with hypertension, and the altered metabolism may contribute to symptoms such as hypoglycemia and increased appetite.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Oral leukoplakia related conditions (e.g., oral cancer, HPV infections)

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause hypothyroidism, or underactive thyroid, leading to delayed puberty and, in some cases, constipation. Hyperthyroidism may present early in the disease.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many organs. Can lead to dysautonomia including Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS), gastrointestinal issues like constipation, and can potentially impact puberty timing.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder that affects females, where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. It can cause delayed puberty and is associated with hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Can cause constipation and delayed puberty due to malabsorption of nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term mainly used to describe two conditions, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, which are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Can cause constipation and may affect growth and development in children, potentially delaying puberty.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. May be associated with POTS and can have overlapping symptoms including gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that occurs in children. Can lead to delayed puberty due to chronic inflammation and use of corticosteroids. Associated lymphadenitis may occasionally occur.

diagnoses.name: Hypopituitarism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the pituitary gland does not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormones, which can lead to a variety of symptoms including delayed puberty, and in rare cases, could be associated with constipation and thyroid dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia Nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight. Can cause constipation, delayed puberty, and thyroid dysfunction, including a state mimicking hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the adrenal glands don't produce enough of the hormone cortisol. This condition can indirectly affect thyroid function and influence the occurrence of symptoms like constipation and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Dyshidrotic eczema
diagnoses.description: A type of eczema characterized by small blisters on the hands and feet, usually related to stress, allergies, or moist hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Functional neurological disorder (conversion disorder)
diagnoses.description: A condition where psychological stress is converted into physical symptoms, such as pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A condition causing involuntary tight closure of the eyelids.

diagnoses.name: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), the body's main energy source.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Hypoglycemia can occur as a complication of insulin treatment.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that can cause hyperactivity or other metabolic disturbances. Includes hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland produces too much of the hormone thyroxine.

diagnoses.name: Chronic anxiety
diagnoses.description: A condition that can present with hyperactivity and can also exacerbate or trigger episodes of pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the central nervous system that affects movement and can cause involuntary movements or spasms, which might be confused with other conditions like blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Though distinct from pseudoseizures, epilepsy must be ruled out in the differential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. Symptoms include nasal congestion, hypoxia due to respiratory distress, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to something you're allergic to, such as peanuts or bee stings. Symptoms include hypoxia, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and severe pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes swelling in various parts of the body, including the face, throat, and abdomen. It can lead to nasal congestion, abdominal cramps, and potentially life-threatening airway blockage.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, hypoxia from severe allergic reactions, angioedema, pruritus, and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction
diagnoses.description: An unexpected reaction to a drug, which can manifest as hypoxia, angioedema, abdominal cramps, pruritus, and nasal congestion. Different from side effects, these reactions are similar to allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, leading to a wide range of chronic symptoms, including angioedema, pruritus, abdominal cramps, and occasionally hypoxia due to respiratory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: A skin rash triggered by a reaction to food, medicine, or other irritants. Symptoms include pruritus, angioedema, and can be associated with systemic reactions including abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. Symptoms can include pruritus, angioedema if swelling is severe, and occasionally, nasal congestion due to allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to insect stings. Common symptoms include pruritus, angioedema, hypoxia in severe reactions, and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Latex Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the proteins present in natural rubber latex. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, pruritus, angioedema, and occasionally, nasal congestion or hypoxia due to respiratory involvement.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like headache, aphasia, and sometimes vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause pressure effects leading to headache, aphasia, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection, presenting with headache, nausea, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, causing headache, fever, confusion, and in some cases, vomiting and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding within the brain tissue itself, which can cause sudden headache, vomiting, and difficulty with speech and understanding.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: An uncommon type of stroke caused by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain, known for causing a sudden severe headache, vomiting, and sometimes difficulty with speech.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily interrupts blood flow to part of the brain, causing symptoms like temporary aphasia and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms before the headache onset, occasionally accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection, causing headache, fever, vomiting, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, and sometimes leading to headaches and vomiting post-seizure.

diagnoses: Neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that involve visual phenomena such as bright spots, shapes, or flashes (scintillation), and light sensitivity (photophobia). Some individuals may also experience ataxia as part of the aura phase.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Some patients may report sensitivity to light (photophobia) or ataxia due to the vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include ataxia, photophobia, and in rare cases, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve that can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, balance issues (ataxia), and in some cases, headache with photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Spinocerebellar Ataxia
diagnoses.description: A progressive, degenerative, genetic disease with multiple types, characteristically leading to ataxia. Some types may indirectly affect vision, leading to photophobia, and rarely affect auditory pathways.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection or inflammation causing balance disturbances (ataxia), hearing loss, and sometimes symptoms such as photophobia due to the associated discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED)
diagnoses.description: An immune system disease that attacks the inner ear, leading to progressive hearing loss and sometimes balance issues (ataxia). Associated symptoms can include sensitivity to light (photophobia).

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Vertigo (Vestibular Migraine)
diagnoses.description: Migraine that may present with vertigo or balance disturbances (ataxia) as a primary symptom, along with traditional migraine symptoms like photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Brainstem or Cerebellar Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurring in areas of the brain that control balance and coordination (ataxia), which may also affect vision (photophobia) and hearing.

diagnoses.name: Mitochondrial Disorders
diagnoses.description: Genetic disorders affecting mitochondrial function, which can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms including ataxia, vision problems like photophobia, and hearing loss.

diagnoses: Evans syndrome (combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis C)
Epilepsy (for seizures, in the context of underlying systemic condition)
